The Hidden Rate Elimination Act of 2001, also known as the "Act," makes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It specifies that changes in tax rates under this Act do not apply to section 15 of the Code. Additionally, the Act includes a reduction in marginal income tax rates for individuals. SEC. 2. REDUCTION IN MARGINAL INCOME TAX RATES FOR INDIVIDUALS. Amends tax rates for married individuals filing joint returns and surviving spouses for the year 2002. The tax rates for taxable income in 2002 are as follows:
- Not over $12,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $12,000 but not over $45,200: $1,680 plus 15% of the excess over $12,000
- Over $45,200 but not over $109,250: $6,660 plus 27% of the excess over $45,200
- Over $109,250 but not over $166,450: $23,953.50 plus 30% of the excess over $109,250
- Over $166,450 but not over $297,300: $41,113.50 plus 35% of the excess over $166,450
- Over $297,300: $86,911 plus 38% of the excess The tax rates for heads of households in 2002 are as follows:
- Over $109,250 but not over $166,450: $23,953.50 plus 30% of the excess
- Over $166,450 but not over $297,300: $41,113.50 plus 35% of the excess
- Over $297,300: $86,911 plus 38% of the excess If taxable income is not over $10,000, the tax is 14% of taxable income. - For income over $148,650, the tax is $43,455.50 plus 38% of the excess. In taxable years after 2002, tax rates from 2002 are reduced by 1 percentage point annually for certain brackets.
